title: Cá Kho Tộ (Caramelized Fish)
description: A classic Vietnamese clay-pot style caramelized fish simmered in a rich sweet-salty sauce with aromatic shallots, garlic, and black pepper. Fish fillets are seared and gently braised until the sauce is deeply caramelized and glossy, perfect over steamed rice.

ingredients.display_name: firm white fish fillets (catfish, cod, or basa), cut into 6-8 pieces
ingredients.notes: skin on or off, cut into 6-8 portions

ingredients.display_name: pork belly, small dice (traditional addition for richness)
ingredients.notes: optional but traditional; cut into small cubes

ingredients.display_name: scallions/green onions, sliced (white + green parts separated)
ingredients.notes: white parts used in braise, green for garnish

ingredients.display_name: granulated sugar (for caramel) or rock sugar
ingredients.notes: for making caramel; adjust to taste

ingredients.display_name: light soy sauce (small amount for color, optional)
ingredients.notes: optional for extra color and umami

ingredients.display_name: fresh red bird's eye chili (sliced) or 1 small red chili

steps.text: Prepare ingredients: pat fish pieces dry, slice shallots, mince garlic, slice scallions separating white and green parts, and cut pork belly if using.
Heat a wide heavy-bottomed pot or clay pot over medium heat; add sugar and a tablespoon of oil. Melt sugar into an amber caramel, swirling the pan but not burning it.
Once caramel is amber, immediately add the white parts of scallions, shallots, and minced garlic; stir briefly to coat and release aroma, then add diced pork belly (if using) and sear for color.
Add fish pieces in a single layer and sear gently for 1–2 minutes per side to set color without breaking the fillets.
Pour in fish sauce, optional soy sauce, and enough water or stock to come about halfway up the fish pieces; bring to a gentle simmer. Scrape any browned bits into the liquid.
Reduce heat to low; cover with a loose lid and simmer gently for 12–15 minutes so the fish cooks through and the sauce concentrates. Spoon sauce over fish occasionally.

Remove lid and simmer uncovered for another 6–8 minutes to thicken and caramelize the sauce to a glossy coating; adjust heat to avoid burning. Taste and adjust saltiness with more fish sauce if needed and stir in black pepper and sliced chili if using.
Turn off heat and sprinkle green parts of scallions over the fish. Let rest 2 minutes in the pot for flavors to settle.
Serve hot directly from the pot or transfer to a serving dish with steamed rice alongside, spooning extra caramel sauce over rice.
